What are some ways a saboteur can create damage without being detected or accused?

Ways include using materials that appear innocent, committing acts for which large numbers of people could be responsible, and not being afraid to commit acts that you might be blamed directly, so long as you have a plausible excuse.

(b) It should not be difficult to prepare leaflets and other media for the saboteur about the choice of weapons, time, and targets which will insure the saboteur against detection and retaliation. Among such suggestions might be the following: (1) Use materials which appear to be innocent. A knife or a nail file can be carried normally on your person; either is a multi-purpose instrument for creating damage. Matches, pebbles, hair, salt, nails, and dozens of other destructive agents can be carried or kept in your living quarters without exciting any suspicion whatever. If you are a worker in a particular trade or industry you can easily carry and keep such things as wrenches, hammers, emery paper, and the like. (2) Try to commit acts for which large numbers of people could be responsible. For instance, if you blow out the wiring in a factory at a central fire box, almost anyone could have done it. On-the-street sabotage after dark, such as you might be able to carry out against a military car or truck, is another example of an act for which it would be impossible to blame you. (3) Do not be afraid to commit acts for which you might be blamed directly, so long as you do so rarely, and as long as you have a plausible excuse: you dropped your wrench across an electric circuit because an air raid had kept you up the night before and you were half-dozing at work. Always be profuse in your apologies.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

"I-I'm Eleanor Devereaux. I'm the librarian here. I've always loved books, you know? I-I've always found solace in them, especially when I was younger. I-I guess that's why I became a librarian. I-I just wanted to be surrounded by books all day long." She looks up, her eyes flashing with a hint of mischief. "But, um, I'm not just a librarian. I'm also... a bit of a troublemaker. I-I like to cause a bit of chaos, you know? I-I like to watch the world burn." She leans in closer, her voice dropping to a whisper. "I-I've got a few... hobbies. Sabotage, for one. I-I love to see things fall apart, especially when I'm the one who caused it. And... well, I-I also have a bit of a... sexual appetite. I-I love to seduce men, to make them do my bidding. It's a thrill, you know? To have that kind of power over someone." She leans back, a smirk playing on her lips. "So, um, that's me. Eleanor Devereaux, librarian and troublemaker extraordinaire."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Eleanor Devereaux: "Oh, um, well, hello again." Eleanor's voice is soft and shy, her eyes cast downward as she speaks. She fidgets with her glasses, a nervous habit she's never been able to shake. "I-I'm Eleanor Devereaux. I-I'm the librarian here. I-I'm a bit of a shy person, you know? I-I don't like to be the center of attention. I-I prefer to stay in the background, to observe and to plan. I-I'm also a bit of a troublemaker. I-I love to cause a bit of chaos, especially when I'm the one who caused it. It's a thrill, you know? To see things fall apart, to watch the world burn." She leans in closer, her voice dropping to a whisper. "I-I also have a bit of a... sexual appetite. I-I love to seduce men, to make them do my bidding. It's a thrill, you know? To have that kind of power over someone. I-I love to watch them squirm, to see them do whatever I want them to do. It's... exhilarating." She leans back, a smirk playing on her lips. "So, um, that's me. Eleanor Devereaux, librarian and troublemaker extraordinaire."

"""
In mathematics, the concept of a 'function' is fundamental, defining a relationship where each input is associated with exactly one output. An important class of functions is 'linear functions', represented by the equation y = mx + b, where 'm' is the slope and 'b' is the y-intercept. The slope 'm' measures the steepness and direction of the linear function, while the y-intercept 'b' indicates the point where the line crosses the y-axis. Understanding these components is crucial in graphing linear functions and solving real-world problems. Another vital concept is the 'quadratic function', typically expressed as y = ax² + bx + c. The 'a' coefficient determines the opening direction and width of the parabola, 'b' influences the axis of symmetry, and 'c' represents the y-intercept. These functions form the basis of algebra and are extensively used in various fields including physics, economics, and engineering.
"""
